Author: StoppableHulk

Comment: >“I meant what I said when I started,” he continued. “I’m preparing to hand this to the next generation. It’s a transition government. But things moved so quickly that it made it difficult to walk away.”  This quote is particularly telling... a lot of people on reddit defending Biden before he dropped out were very aggressive in saying he never said he would be a one term president when he ran in 2020... Well here it is from the horse's mouth, confirmation that he signaled exactly that.  It makes the decision to stay in for so long in 2024 even harder to parse honestly. Did his time in office just make him totally delusional?
Author: RimboTheRebbiter

Comment: The economy simply didn’t improve enough, fast enough, for enough voters across the US. The US has a history of voting out the current party in times of economic hardship. The economy was improving, but it was not yet lifting the entire population (possibly because the economy has shifted in a way that CAN’T lift the entire population). As a result, desperate people voted for “something else”. By and large this is reason the Democrats lost. It really didn’t matter who the candidate was (although it would have helped if whoever the candidate was would have made a clean break from Biden to convince people another Democratic term would improve things in a meaningful way. With Kamala, it was too easy for people to say “if she had all these ideas, and they’re so good, then why hasn’t she already worked to implement them before now?”. Personally, I think the Democrats were doomed from the start because too many people were still hurting economically.
Author: Austin_Peep_9396

Comment: **From reporter Ron Dicker:**  Former President Joe Biden said in a new interview that the timing of his pullout from the 2024 election wouldn’t have made a difference, suggesting that Kamala Harris’ loss to Donald Trump was inevitable.   “Should you have withdrawn earlier?” the BBC’s Nick Robinson asked in the interview, shared Wednesday.  “I don’t think it would’ve mattered,” Biden replied. “We left at a time when we had a good candidate. She was fully funded.”  The former president said he and his administration were “so successful in our agenda” that it became hard for him to say, “I’m gonna stop now.”  “I meant what I said when I started,” he continued. “I’m preparing to hand this to the next generation. It’s a transition government. But things moved so quickly that it made it difficult to walk away.”  Here's a link to the full article: [https://www.huffpost.com/entry/joe-biden-dont-think-it-wouldve-mattered\_n\_681b34d1e4b0529436a1a8ae?utm\_medium=Social&utm\_source=reddit&utm\_campaign=us\_main](https://www.huffpost.com/entry/joe-biden-dont-think-it-wouldve-mattered_n_681b34d1e4b0529436a1a8ae?utm_medium=Social&utm_source=reddit&utm_campaign=us_main)
Author: huffpost

Comment: Honestly I strong doubt it would have made a difference too.  More time means more time for Republicans to demonize a female candidate.   There is a small percentage of people who say and think they would vote for a female presidential candidate who when they get to the polls vote for a male instead.  Its likely about 3-4% (about 1 in 25-30) and that is enough to flip an election.   Also, there was about 45% of the population that to some extent believed Trump's blatant lies who voted for him, and the electoral college favors Republicans.
